reference.shortdesc: The steptroubleshooting element contains information that is designed to help remedy the situation when a step does not complete as expected.

section.title: Usage information
section.note: Do not use <note type="trouble"> inside of the steptroubleshooting element.
section.draft-comment:
Seems like an explanation of why not would be useful.
Kris Eberlein, 19 October 2022
This is content that JoAnn and Bob Thomas insisted on adding in DITA 1.3. In 13, the full note read as follows:
"Do not use <note type="trouble"> inside of <steptroubleshooting> because its meaning there would be ambiguous."
Robert questioned what "would be ambiguous" meant, so I removed that. Can you suggest different wording? I think the original intent was that having such a note in the <steptroubleshooting> element was inherently ambiguous – that it would be unclear whether the note applied to the step or the actual <steptroubleshooting> element.
Kris Eberlein, 20 October 2022
I talked with Dawn today. We both agree that this note should be removed. It's appropriate for guidelines for an implementation, but not the spec. And I removed it from this topic and the <tasktroubleshooting> topic.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The steptroubleshooting element is specialized from div. It is defined in the task module.

example.title: Example
example.p: The following code sample shows how the steptroubleshooting element specifies the troubleshooting actions that a user can take if the step does not complete as they expected:
example.codeblock:
Log in to the system

The Welcome screen appears.

If the Welcome screen does not appear, try one or more of the following actions:

  • Verify that the user name was entered correctly
  • Verify that the password was entered correctly
  • Confirm that the maintenance contract is still active
